docs.lead_paragraph: Last night a lecture was delivered in Broadway Tabernacle by Dr. John H. Griscom, upon the Physiological, Chemical and Mechanical principles of Respiration, as showing the means and importance of Ventilation. There was a highly respectable audience present, and much attention was paid to the enlightened suggestions of the lecturer.

headline.main: LECTURES FOR THE PEOPLE.; The Importance of Proper Vetilation. A LECTURE--BY DR. GRISCOM. The Importance of Proper Vetilation. A LECTURE.

byline.original: By Telegraph to The New-York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Tile Senate met at 12? o'clock. A Message was received from the President, inclosing a [Report of the Secretary of State, calling attention to the payment of the next installment of the Mexican indemnity. REPORTS, , Mr. SEWARD presented certain resolutions of the Corporation of New-York, offering to the United States suitable grounds in that city for the erection of a Mint. A number of petitions and reports of a private character were presented.

docs.lead_paragraph: SUPERIOR COURT--Before Chief Justice OAKLEY and a Special Jury. CATHERINE N. FORREST vs. EDWIN FORREST. TWENTY-SEVENTH DAY. The gallery of the Court-room was full, with the usual auditory, long before the time for commencing proceedings, and then those who were excluded had the pleasure of taking a promenade in the Park, as none but witnesses and members of the bar, or other persons having business in the Court-room,

byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

docs.lead_paragraph: During the week preceding Christmas, attention is, for the most part, much more earnestly directed to social than to public matters. Instead of being devoted to the sublime science of politics, the popular aspirations are much more strongly fixed on such sublunary things as turkies, geese, and plum puddings, together with other needful preliminaries and accessories to the festivities of the season.

docs.lead_paragraph: There was about the usual attendance this morning of spectators, the officers in attendance taking extra precautions to prevent a crowd on the staircase and passages leading to the Court Room. Mrs. Forrest and Mrs. N. P. Willis came in before the Jurors were called, and retired to the private room of the Judge.

docs.lead_paragraph: --SOME NOTICES of Botanical Literature, by Prof. A. Gray, published in the January number of Silliman's Journal, contain a variety of interesting facts. Prof. Gray notices particularly the remarkable mortality which has recently occurred among the German botanists.

headline.main: Scientific Intelligence.; Carefully Prepared for the New-York Daily Times.

docs.abstract: On Recollections of the N.Y. Press
docs.lead_paragraph: The New-York Typographical Society gave its annual Banquet, on the anniversary of FRANKLIN'S birthday, last evening, at Niblo's Saloon. The company, seven or eight hundred in number, sat down at about 9 o'clock, Mr. JAMES WHITE presiding.
docs.snippet: The New-York Typographical Society gave its annual Banquet, on the anniversary of FRANKLIN'S birthday, last evening, at Niblo's Saloon. The company, seven or eight hundred in number, sat down at about 9 o'clock, Mr. JAMES WHITE presiding.

headline.main: THE TYPOGRAPHICAL FESTIVAL.; BANQUET OF THE PRINTERS. SPEECH OF DR. FRANCIS.

docs.lead_paragraph: At Philadelphia, some weeks since, Dr. CHARLES D. MEIGS read before the Academy of Natural Sciences, in the hall of the University of Pennsylvania, a biographical memoir of Dr. SAMUEL GEORGE MORTON, late President of the Academy.
